placeInfo/address: 719/1 Galle Rd, Hikkaduwa 80000 Sri Lanka
roomTip: Reading the reviews on Trip Advisor the sea view rooms would seem to be much better than our dark "garden view" room but there is a further price differential and we thought our room was overpriced.
text: At half the price we paid this hotel would be fine but it is incredibly overpriced for the facilities available.  The building itself is quite ugly, the garden and pool area pool are very average and the beach very steep, not safe for swimming (red flag out all 3 days we were there) with several packs of dogs roaming.  Our room was described as "garden view: but the garden was a very small highly walled courtyard filled with a few plants.  Whilst not unattractive in itself it wasn't a "garden" view and made our room dark for most of the day.  There was certainly nowhere we could sit outside our room and see the sun or any view of anything.  The cost for our daughter to share our room with us was also outrageous.  The rooms are described as suites but ours was simply a large room with an outdoor bathroom.  The room, whilst dark, was nicely decorated with a big flat screen tv with international channels. There was a nice fruit bowl and biscuits in the room when we arrived.  The restaurant was a vast open-air concrete area under the hotel and akin to a nicely decorated bus garage.  It did however have a nice view over the small lawned area down to the sea.  Prices in the restaurant weren't far off London prices and significantly more than we paid elsewhere.  The food was mostly good with a reasonable choice and the best thing about the hotel was the staff and the level of service they provided.  They anticipated our needs and were very good.  At the price we paid and from looking at the photos and reading the reviews I has hoping for something idyllic and this certainly wasn't that.  It's a very average hotel (building and location) but with good staff and mostly good food.
title: Hugely disappointed

ownerResponse/text:
Ayubowan!

We are sorry that you were disappointed with your experience at Aditya, and we always welcome constructive criticism. However, we have to take issue with some of your comments. We feel they grossly misrepresent the nature of our hotel, make thoughtless generalizations about our clientele, and impugn the culture of our country.

You claim that your suite was not cleaned before you occupied it, and that the plunge pool had stagnant water. We clean our suites thoroughly as soon as they are vacated by departing guests. The plunge pools are drained and scrubbed as a matter of course, and then refilled with fresh water. If the suite and pool were not to your satisfaction for any reason, you could have brought it to our attention at the time. We have no record or recollection of such a complaint.

Contrary to your assertions, the photographs of the property on our website are as accurate and authentic as possible. We have not enhanced or doctored them in any way. If there are any doubts, Tripadvisor users can easily access traveller photos and compare them with our own.

We regret that you found our interior decoration and lighting not to your liking, but that is a matter of taste. To each his/her own. It’s worth noting that an overwhelming  majority of our guests have commented very favourably and commended the Aditya style. 

Our plunge pools are intended to provide a cool, refreshing dip in the privacy of the suite on our usual sunny days and warm nights.

Our restaurant is open to the sounds and breezes coming from the sea. Again the vast majority of our guests enjoy that airy beachside ambience. They also tend to be extremely positive and complimentary about the meals we serve, as you yourself have pointed out. 

You are, however, wholly incorrect in your presumption that our food items are pre-made and stored in freezers. Nothing could be further from the truth. We do not even have a cold-room at Aditya. Only certain meats and other imported ingredients are stored in a freezer. Every dish we serve is prepared to order from the freshest produce we can source.

It is unfortunate that you have made a glib and erroneous reference to Sri Lankan ‘culture’. Whatever our other faults, the revolting behaviour you have described is certainly not the norm in this country. In our 7 years of operation, we have never observed such a phenomenon on our stretch of beach, nor have any of our guests ever reported it.

Equally ill-considered is your contention that anyone who thinks Aditya is exclusive or luxurious should have their mental stability questioned. We have only 12 rooms. Each is an individually decorated suite with a minimum of 750 sq. ft. of space. Each has a private plunge pool, a private garden view or an expansive balcony with a sea view. We are a Tripadvisor 2013 Traveler’s Choice Winner in the Luxury, Best Service, and Small Hotel categories. We’ll leave the readers with these indisputable facts, and urge them to draw their own conclusions. 

Regards,
Shami & the Aditya Team
placeInfo/address: 719/1 Galle Rd, Hikkaduwa 80000 Sri Lanka
text:
I am completely baffled by the good reviews for the Aditya Resort as I was totally underwhelmed by the place. There's certainly far more impressive boutique hotels on Sri Lanka. I am so pleased that I could only get a 2 night stay. I had originally planned to stay a week. Thank heavens that didn't happen.

I think what really bugs me is the way the owner of this hotel describes it as 'exclusive and luxurious' - clearly he's never been to such places, if he had he'd realise he's got a long way to go before joining the upper ranks of boutique hospitality. This hotel, built in 2006, somehow manages to feel like something from the 1970's which could feature in a British sitcom supposedly filmed in Spain. The awful TV show Duty Free comes to mind.

What is very clear to me is that most people come to Sri Lanka and do a tour of the country - all inland - and their final day or two is spent by the beach. And after travelling inland I can totally understand how a little place by the beach can seem like heaven. However, apart from Colombo, I have only stayed at small hotels on the coast and worked my way around some of the islands beaches. And I'm sorry to say the Aditya was the most disappointing - and the only one I shall completely erase from my memory.

1. Our room upon arrival hadn't been cleaned properly. The previous occupants were obviously smokers as the ashtrays were still full. And the water in the plunge pool was stangnant. So I have no idea how many previous occupants may have used it.

2. There are some attractive photos on the website of the suites, and even though we booked one of the better ones, our suite wasn't as remotely appealing as anything on the website.

3. I found the decoration of the hotel gaudy - orange and lime green should never be seen unless in a fruit bowl. And whoever thought someone would want to wake up of a morning and see a lime green wall ....

4. The lighting in our Ocean View Suite was awful. A wonderful huge room - but such  uninspiring decoration. They really should hire an interior decorator to do something amazing. The whole hotel is crying out for someone to do something incredible with it. But I very much suspect the owner has also dictated the interior design - and to be blunt - he has no flair or taste for such matters.

5. Contrary to some other reviews I liked the bathroom - nice and big - and I liked that it was open to the elements. Not sure of the point of a cold water plunge pool /Jacuzzi unless you can have a warm soak in it. Do people have cold Jacuzzis?There were even bath salts on the side for the Jacuzzi - but who puts bath salts in cold water? Anyway, as previously mentioned the water in it had not been cleaned and was stagnant, so we weren't going to use it. So that was a waste of money. The shower space in the bathroom is nice and large - but the shower head only pokes out a small way from the wall so you end up bashing your arms and elbos against the taps whilst trying to get under the water. Poor design.

6. I never did like the photos of the open restaurant, so I guess I can't complain about not liking the real thing. I thought it had all the charm of an outdoor canteen. Again, it's begging for an interior designer to do something incredible with the space. And once again, someone lacking in any taste selected the most ridiculous cutlery to ever be handled. Ugly and awkward.

7. The suite had a good hard bed (if you like hard beds) .. and I guess the hotel owner has a sense of humour considering there was a copy of the Kama Sutra on the bedside table ( I guess it makes a change from the Bible which no one reads). And he also includes a condom in the bathroom. Make of that what you will ...

8. At nearly $550 a night, definitely not worth it, and that didn't even include breakfast. I'll happily pay double that price if something is good. But this was $550 a night down the drain.

9. I'm certainly not going to knock any of the staff. They all try their best and are willing to assist. Plus, the hotel was kept clean. And thank heavens there was no piped music.

10. The pool area is small - thankfully very few people were staying here at the same time as us so the area was quiet. The hotel isn't on a great stretch of beach it reminded me of many in India - it's more like a locals beach - though that's not a complaint. All day it's deserted, then around 4 or 5pm mothers and fathers bring their children to do their ablutions .. and if you're unlucky you will come across men doing their 'toilet' duties and burying it in the sand. But that's the culture - you have to accept it. However, there are far more beautiful 'postcard perfect' beaches in Sri Lanka.

11. Many have reviewed the food, and those reviews swayed me into staying here. I thought this was going to be the Aditya's saving grace. It wasn't. The menu is far too vast. There is no chef on God's earth that can cook good Sri Lankan, Indian, Thai, Chinese, Japanese, Italian and various other dishes all to an excellent standard in one kitchen. It's impossible. The endlessly manhandled 'menus' put before you have way too many options, and your mind will create a scene from Gordon Ramsey's Kitchen Nightmares where he discovers, as always, that menus this vast contain masses of pre-prepared dishes stored in freezers. And that's exactly what you get here. I ate food that I know for certain was not freshly prepared, and what was put before me had all the taste and allure of cardboard. Of course, the hotel owner will disagree and state everything is freshly made, but I know different. The menus here will excite the Nando's and Denny's customer. Junk food with a long shelf life, covered in gloopy sauces, full of additives. And it's many of these same people who will think the Aditya is an 'exclusive luxury boutique' which isn't remotely exclusive or luxurious. It's a mid-range small hotel mostly catering to the package holiday traveller, and that's why you wont find it on any websites that promote 'exclusive luxurious' properties.

If anyone truly leaves the Aditya thinking this is an exclusive luxurious hotel then I will question their mental stability or presume they are new to travel.
title: A Luxury Boutique Hotel For Those That Think Nando's Is Fine Dining.

ownerResponse/text:
We are glad to note that you enjoyed your stay at Aditya and thank you for the kind comments.

Please accept our sincere apologies to both you and your girlfriend for the inconvenience caused. This is the first time we have had a guest comment of this nature (prying eyes). Practically all our staff are well experienced in the hotel industry and we find it difficult to even hazard a guest at anyone who may be responsible. Even though your comment comes to us three months after your stay at Aditya we will definitely look into this matter.

Aditya strives to be a heaven of tranquility and relaxation providing the traveler with peace and privacy coupled with a high level of service. Galle town, on the one hand, is a World heritage site the grew out of Old Dutch fort - one of the few living forts in the world. Owing to its very nature and situation Galle is not a practical location of a Boutique hotel. Hikkaduwa on the other hand is a bustling seaside resort, popular with both foreign and local tourists and has all the attractions such places usually offer,- cheaper accommodation, restaurants, bars, night spots, water sports, beach carnivals, etc. Here again the very nature of the place is not conducive to a hotel such as ours. Our location is equidistant between just a few kilometers away from these two attractions. Perhaps the advertising does not make this clear enough. Bar prices are on par with other hotels of a similar nature in Sri Lanka.
placeInfo/address: 719/1 Galle Rd, Hikkaduwa 80000 Sri Lanka
text:
Firstly let me say that overall we did enjoy my stay, i was travelling with my girlfriend and we enjoyed the food, clean rooms, open air dining and closeness to the sea. 

We did not enjoy:   1) the prying eyes of the hotel staff every time my girlfriend went to swim in the Hotel pool,she became so paranoid that she ended up swimming with her shirt over her costume. 2)  The Hotel needs to advertise the location, which is between Hikkaduwa  and Galle, not walking distance to anything, so you are stuck, somewhere but nowhere. 3) The high alcohol prices.

The Hotel has loads of  potential but could do with  work to bring it up to par with other Hotels in the area.
title: potential is there but needs help

ownerResponse/text:
Saw the review of 26th July 2007 by tichu. We thought it prudent to conduct a thorough check of the contents as well as wait for further reviews before responding.

The incident reflects a mis-understanding of the terms of booking. It is hotel policy to charge for children above 04 years. Our Manager, Mr.Neomal Jinadasa conveyed this to the guest who arrived with a child of around 11 years. She said she had been informed that children were on free-of-charge basis. Mr. Jinadasa then accepted the booking out of courtesy without levying any charge for the child and the matter appeared to have been settled. 
 
The en-suite plunge pool remains an important attraction but none of our plunge pools have hot water facilities nor do we at any point claim to have this facility. Our guests enjoy the cool waters of our pools in the balmy 30 degree sunshine. Our staff has no reason to therefore ‘reluctantly admit’ to a lack of hot water in the plunge pools. All our expansive and luxurious bathrooms are well equipped with hot and cold water.

Aditya has from its inception welcomed guests seeking a ‘romantic getaway’ to take advantage of its secluded accommodation and quiet unobtrusive service  Our success in this direction has led to Aditya becoming a popular destination for weddings / honeymoons ( please see fuzzypeg08 – Jan 25, 2008 ) with special packages on offer to both local and foreign visitors.

Shamindra Fernando
General Manager
placeInfo/address: 719/1 Galle Rd, Hikkaduwa 80000 Sri Lanka
text:
I had heard a lot of positive things about this Hotel, and thought it would be the ideal place to spend my wedding anniversery.
I contacted the hotel direct and made the reservations  for an ocean view room and also told them that I would be there for my wedding anniversery.
On checking into the hotel, the duty manager (I think) Neomal was quite offhandish for no apparent reason and created a very bad first impression.
The rooms were quite nice, with the plunge pool being the main feature of the bathroom. Unfortunately we found the hot water was not working and we were shifted to another room after about three hours. The pool in the new room was also not functioning and the hotel staff  reluctantly admitted all the rooms on the floor had the same problem.
Dinner was nice but I was disappointed with the lack of any special arrangement for my anniversery despite telling them when I made the reservation.
Overall the hotel is a bit overated and overpriced for the facilities on offer and a fair amount of training is required for the front office/reception staff.
title: Could be much better

ownerResponse/text:
Dear Christopher,

We have conducted a thorough review of your stay with us and genuinely feel you may have misunderstood what it is that we offer at The Wallawwa. 

We do not promise to be a five star hotel. We take great pride in the boutique character and peaceful ambiance of the Wallawwa and understand from reading your other reviews that our style of property simply doesn’t suit you. We are not, and neither do we claim to be, anything like the Four Seasons Hotel Group that you clearly enjoy. 

The Wallawwa is an 18th century manor house that was transformed to an 18-bedroom luxury boutique hotel just over 10 years ago, preserving the colonial style and atmosphere of the 200 year old building. As you can see from other past reviews, we have been praised many times for having a unique style and character as well as friendly, efficient staff and delicious food, both Sri Lankan and International.

We are unsure how you can state that our non-Sri Lankan food was “not even mediocre”, as you both ordered Sri Lankan food (Ceylon Spiced Prawns and Chicken Curry) for your dinner. If you could provide us with some specific feedback, that would be very helpful.

With regards to the spa, one of our Spa Therapists was on duty all day and only carried out two other treatments, so there was plenty of time for you to book your treatments had you requested. Unfortunately, the second therapist was on leave on the day of your stay, so a twin treatment wouldn’t have been possible. 

We’re sorry you felt like the road was dirty and crowded, but that does not have anything to do with the hotel. It is the same road that is used to get to our international airport just 15 minutes away, and one of the reasons we are acclaimed for our fantastic location. 

Finally, we’re not sure who had warned you about the snakes ‘in the region’, but Sri Lanka is known for its rich biodiversity and is something we are proud of. There are snakes found all over Sri Lanka, however the majority of them are non-venomous and are rarely seen. In over 10 years of operating hotels in Sri Lanka we have never (fortunately) had a problem with the local wildlife that shares their habitat with us. We’re sorry that it stopped you from swimming in the pool or walking around the property, but had you spoken to a member of staff, they would have most certainly accompanied you around our beautiful tropical garden.

We do appreciate constructive criticism and our team are always open to suggestions and feedback. However, rather than just posting a poor review online, we’d recommend that you raise any concerns you have whilst you’re at a hotel, so the team can do their best to put your mind at rest on the spot. 

Best regards,
The Wallawwa
placeInfo/address: Minuwangoda Road, Kotugoda Sri Lanka
roomTip: Book another hotel.
text:
We purchased a Sri Lankan custom tour package from A and K and were promised and excellent trip...Well it wasn’t as advertised to say the least. We have travelled using A and K multiple global packages and they definitely are no longer the premium  tour operator that they were yet their prices are still 5 star.
     We spoke at length about our considerations and desires for this trip and were promised that this was an excellent boutique hotel just outside  Columbo, Sri Lanka. Realistically it is in the boonies off a dirty two lane highway that is extremely crowded and down a dirt road...Not what we expected. 
     It is an old colonial style house that is well maintained if not luxurious. We were not happy with the delux room we paid for , so paid extra to upgrade to the largest most delux suite. It was very spacious, but not luxurious, yet did have a private plunge pool. We had travelled for more than 12 hours to get here and once we had showered and changed , went to their restaurant for dinner. The food quality was not even mediocre. If you ate Sri Lankan food it was mediocre, if not it was less than acceptable. We tried to book massages after the long flights over many times zones, but they had only one masseuse available and would not call in additional staff, so the spa was a joke. The staff were all very nice, but poorly trained.
      Although we had rudimentary international cable and A/C the room also came with lizards and spiders sprawling up the walls. The large trees and grounds were beautiful, but we were warned that poisonous / deadly snakes were in the region , thus we stayed away from walking amount the trees or the swimming pool.  We would not recommend the property.
title: Poor location , nice people, definitely not 5 star

ownerResponse/text:
Dear Emma,
Thank you for your feedback on TripAdvisor. 

I am saddened to hear that you did not like our Garden Suite which has been praised by many guests in the past. However, I do understand that tastes and preferences can differ from person to person and I apologise if this room did not appeal to you.

We’ve investigated your early departure thoroughly and our Front Office member of staff on duty was informed by your husband that you planned to leave due to our hotel not being near the beach. In none of our marketing material do we claim to be near the beach and at no stage was he informed of the reasons you attribute to your early departure in your review. This meant he had no opportunity to show you other room categories and didn’t raise it with the Resident Manager at the time, as he had received no indication that you were unhappy. As soon as our Resident Manager heard that you’d chosen to leave he contacted you at your new hotel to check that everything was ok, so I think it’s unfair to say that we didn’t reach out to you since your departure, and that you’re still awaiting a phone call from us.

With regards to being charged $750 at checkout, I am afraid you may have misunderstood our payment terms. You were booked under our promotional offer “3 nights for the price of 2”. This denotes that you pay for 2 nights and stay a third night on a complimentary basis. This was the offer you have specifically requested for when inquiring through our website, and once the late check out and airport transfers would have been added, the total would have been $950.

Although our cancellation policy is to charge the total amount of the reservation, the staff accommodated your request to pay only 2 nights (and the airport pick up transfer), and you were happy with this at the time, as you state in your review. The late checkout fee together with the airport drop off transfer which was originally booked was waived off.

Despite the several very positive comments about our property and team members, we are disappointed that your experience did not meet your expectations, but feel that we have been lenient by waiving the charges for the pre-booked late check out and airport transfer, despite the losses we encountered due to your early departure. 

As the above shows, we don’t believe we’ve handled this situation in anything but a professional and understanding way and hope that both you and others reading this will see that the charges made were reasonable given the sudden decision to leave with no explanation at the time other than your desire to be near the beach.

If you have any further queries or require further clarification, please do contact me directly on henry@teardrop-hotels.com.

Warm regards,
Henry

Henry Fitch
Managing Director
placeInfo/address: Minuwangoda Road, Kotugoda Sri Lanka
text:
Let me first start by saying we booked a short break to Sri Lanka for 3 nights. Intention being to use this hotel as a base and somewhere to relax, close to airport and therefore not a lot of time spent in transport, as the roads are busy etc.

Picked up from airport and the driver was very pleasant. Arrived 4 am checked into a luxury garden suite. There was nothing luxury about this room or the yard like outdoor space. 
Sheets had marks on them the bathroom was like something out of a prison movie. Not to my taste. 

We decided to sleep and leave the next morning as this was not going to be a relaxing space for 3 days.

We had prepaid for 3 .5 nights, my husband spoke to the staff politely and told them it's not what we wanted and amicably suggested we would pay for 2 nights and then we would leave. The staff very helpfully arranged some transport for us and we decided to go to a different hotel which we have stayed in before. 

He paid the bill then later that day the hotel did call us to ask why we checked out, we then realised we had been charged $750 for staying in this hotel for 8 hours.

Several phone calls to them later and the overall bill being $950.  They refused to refund us any money and suggested that we could come back and stay for a free night.

I'd not ever want to step foot in this place again, staff very helpful if u want somewhere to rest your head before heading home or for 1 night on way in to Sri Lanka, that's the only reason to stay here.

We made a mistake in choosing this hotel , they charged us almost $100 per hour to stay there.

I'm still waiting for the phone call back more than a week later. 

Very disgruntled customer and the fact  that this hotel has not reached out to since terrible customer service . They must feel that they have given us a fair deal. I as a customer don't think $100 per hour is fair.
title: Terrible Customer Service

ownerResponse/text:
Dear	 VandEm59

Thank you for your feedback via Trip Advisor. 

We’re very sorry to hear that you didn’t have an exceptional time at the Wallawwa and have looked into the comments that you’ve mentioned.

It’s great to hear that you enjoyed our lovely rooms and bathrooms, however we’re sorry that you didn’t find the private courtyard enticing. We’ve raised this concern with the estate manager who is in the process of some landscaping work to improve the courtyard in the room you were in. 

We have a relatively new and well serviced A/C unit in the room that you stayed in, so this is the first we’ve heard about it not working well. We have checked up on this already and it seems to be functioning properly, but we’re sorry if the remote had been set to the wrong setting. Strangely enough the guest staying in the same room the night before mentioned how lovely and cool the room was!

It’s a shame you didn’t try one of our options of main dishes at the restaurant. We cater to an international clientele, and aim to offer a wide variety of dishes – from the Ceylonese Red Chicken Curry to the Vegetarian Gnocchi or Rib Eye Steak. That said, we are also in the process of updating our dinner menu, but do feel that the food offered at our restaurant is some of the best in Sri Lanka, and is certainly no more expensive than similar hotels. Had you mentioned at the time, I’m sure our chef would have been happy to customize any dishes to suit your needs. We’ll also look into your feedback regarding the breakfast option and make any necessary amendments.

We are glad you enjoyed walking around our wonderful garden. Our menu card indeed mentions that some ingredients used are fresh from our garden, as well as the papaya and pineapple juice served upon arrival, which are both grown on the property.

Legally we have to have a board showing the opening times of the swimming pool. Had you mentioned that you’d have liked a swim after the 6pm ‘closing time’ the staff would happily have provided towels and sunbed cushions. The reason for this closing time is that it’s when the sun sets here in Sri Lanka, so seemed to us a sensible time to put the cushions etc away.

We’re extremely surprised about your feelings about the team, as so many reviews have mentioned that our staff – or family as we consider them – do go above and beyond their duty with a smile on their face and a never ending desire to ensure guests are happy. Having operated this hotel for over 8 years, we’ve had many same-sex couples who have come to stay and thoroughly enjoyed their time with us. We’re sorry you didn’t feel the same. 

We do hope to have you back at the Wallawwa, in order to show you the improvements we are making and so you can enjoy the wonderful experience that most of our guests have. If you would like to visit again, please contact me directly on sales@teardrop-hotels.com. 

Warm regards,

India Searle
Guest Relations & Operations
placeInfo/address: Minuwangoda Road, Kotugoda Sri Lanka
text:
The Wallawwa Hotel. We stayed there recently and it was the last hotel of our holiday.  We were looking forward to our stay after reading the reviews. The hotel is located approximately 7 kilometres from the airport, which was ideal for an early flight. 
We were able to compare this hotel to the others we stayed in during our 16 day holiday. 
This sadly, was the most disappointing accommodation. The rooms are big and spacious and have a lovely bathroom. But that is where it ends. We had a private court yard, which was not enticing to sit in. The air conditioning was not appropriate for the room and we were uncomfortable all night, even though it was set on 18 degrees and the fan was turned up full. The AC was extremely noisy but not effective, and we did not sleep well. This made our long travel back home even more tiring, instead of being refreshed to start the journey home. 
The dinner menu was very uninteresting. We opted for 2 entrees only, as none of the mains sounded particularly appealing. We then had dessert and the resulting bill was high for what we consumed. The food was average. We were given a packed breakfast to take to the airport, and it was very poor value, given that we had a bed and breakfast booking. The sandwiches looked like they had been prepared and toasted the evening before and the bacon fat had seeped through the toasted bread. They were inedible. 
On a positive note, the grounds were lovely. We showed ourselves around and we noticed that the hotel has its own fruit and vegetable garden, which excited us. Fresh from the garden to our plates, we thought. The menu obviously did not highlight that fact. The pool hours don't work for a one night stay with an early departure the next morning. After a long, hot drive we were looking forward to a refreshing swim before dinner. Pool hours were 7am - 6pm, and we arrived around 5.30pm. Our morning pick-up was next day at 5am. None of the other hotels had these short hours. 
The staff were not very friendly or warm, which was a different experience to every other hotel we stayed at in Sri Lanka. Everywhere else the staff made you feel welcome and valued. At the Wallawwa Hotel  perhaps it was because we were a same-sex couple. The whole place lacked atmosphere and the high standard we'd expected. 
We stayed at a cheaper hotel in Negombo on our first night in Sri Lanka, which was close to the airport. We will be staying there again next visit. I can't recommend this hotel and we are sorry we stayed here on our last night.
title: Disappointing last night of a fabulous holiday.

ownerResponse/text:
Dear ivylicious,

Thank you for your feedback via Trip Advisor. 

We are, however, extremely disappointed to receive 2 out of 5 from yourself and your partner (in the other review) as it is always our intention to ensure no guest is ever dissatisfied.  If you had voiced your concerns during your stay we would be more than happy to have addressed any issues then and there. The Wallawwa has history dating back to the 18th century, with residents such as the Head Chieftain of Galle and the Royal Air Force, so although it is not comparable to ‘other newer hotels in Sri Lanka’, we offer a range of activities both in and outside the hotel for guests that want to do more than relax by our tranquil pool. 

We’re sorry to hear that you were not satisfied with the delicious vegetarian/vegan options that we provide (for example the goats cheese tart, various pastas, soups, salads, pizza, or even the Sri Lankan vegetarian Cadju Nut & Green Pea curry or Kottu Roti). As we cater for travelers coming from all parts of the world, and do not wish to offer buffet style dining, we offer an a la carte menu that covers both international cuisine and authentic local dishes. As other reviews suggest, the food offered at The Wallawwa is generally exceptionally well received, so we’re sorry to hear that you weren’t impressed with your dinner.

As I hope you saw, we have our own fruit and vegetable garden meaning much of the food that arrives on your plate has travelled no more than 100 metres. So whilst we do apologise if it was not up to your expectations, we do make every effort to ensure we use the finest and freshest ingredients possible.

As for the guests arriving/departing in the rooms next door, we apologise for any disruption caused. Though the walls are 9 inches thick (which is standard for any hotel), it is difficult for us to control a noisy neighbour and we’re extremely sorry that you were disturbed by them. 

Once again, we’re disappointed that you didn’t enjoy your time at The Wallawwa, but will take on board your comments and will look into developing the menu further (we’re actually already working on a new menu that will take effect in September). I do wish you’d raised your concerns at the time so we could try to have put things right, but hope you give us the opportunity to show the service excellence that we’ve become known for if you do return to Sri Lanka. 

If you have any further feedback as to how you feel we can improve, or could have dealt with the matter at the time, please do contact me directly on india@teardrop-hotels.com. 

Warm regards,

India Searle
Guest Relations & Operations
placeInfo/address: Minuwangoda Road, Kotugoda Sri Lanka
text:
We recently stayed for one night at the Wallawwa at the end of our journey. Being able to compare it to other newer hotels in Sri Lanka, I can honestly say that this not worth its money. Rooms look like they were great 5 years ago, nice but nothing special, some details like aircondition and mosquito net look outdated. Walls seem to be thin as a sheet of paper, as our arriving and departing neighbours woke us several times during the night. Having read the comments from previous guests on tripadvisor, we expected delicious food and we have been extremely disappointed...it tasted so boring my wife did not even finish her beloved dhal. Food options read like they try to be international with just a few authentic local dishes.
Ok the gardens and whole property were nice and boutique-style with interesting details but come on you don't have to go to Sri Lanka to sit in the middle of nowhere just for a nice garden and a small swimming pool...
Prices here are ridiculous. They charge you the same amount of money you would pay at brand new 5-star oceanfront-resorts in the south of Sri Lanka, which is by far a better choice if you're looking for worldclass service and up-to-date accomodation.
title: not worth the money at all...

text: I stayed at the Wallawwa for one night in August 2016. The first impression was a nice, cosy, well decorated boutique hotel with friendly staff. The room was nice and clean, but nothing special. Let's talk about the restaurant everyone is raving about: I was deeply disappointed about the food options... Reading the menu made me feel like being in a western country. I mean where were all the delicious vegetarian/vegan options I experienced on my trip through Sri Lanka. The food was not terrible but boring. The pool is small and the garden is nice but nothing too exciting. You can tell that people use this as an "airport hotel" since I was not able to sleep thanks to the rooms next door being very noisy while getting ready to leave between 2 am and 5 am. I have to say that this hotel is way overprized. For 320 $ a night I would expect a lot more.
title: Overprized and outdated

ownerResponse/text:
Dear Bluejay8,

ownerResponse/text:
Dear Bartolasia,

We’re disappointed to read your review about The Wallawwa on Trip Advisor and are extremely keen to hear more about your stay with us so that we can aim to improve. 

In terms of the history and design of the property, we disagree that The Wallawwa is ‘fake’ in any way. The main building, now housing the public areas of the hotel, was built over 200 years ago and renovated 3 years ago at the same time that we built the bedrooms and spa. The furnishings are a combination of genuine Sri Lankan antiques as well as contemporary Asian designed and custom made furniture to ensure comfort and style. The bedrooms and suites are all air conditioned and the temperature can be controlled by the guest occupying the room. Internet access in Sri Lanka is slower than in many parts of the world and can be frustrating – an iMac is located in the study for guests’ use (free of charge) and the rooms are set up to allow wireless access to those traveling with their own laptops/iphones etc. – I apologise if there was any disruption to accessing the internet during your stay.

You say we are ‘impossibly far’ from Colombo – this is not something we can (or would like to) change. As shown on the google map on our website, we are approximately 30km from the city centre and the drive time varies depending on traffic (the journey usually takes 45-60 minutes). The property was chosen due to the proximity to the airport and main roads to many of Sri Lanka’s top tourist destinations, rather than the ease to get to and from the city. We are delighted to be part of a small village in the countryside where we live in harmony with our neighbours and the natural habitat. There is a fantastic array of wildlife in Sri Lanka and we’re pleased they choose to spend some of their time in, or passing through, our beautiful gardens. The birdsong in the morning and various rare trees around the property, in our view, are some of the things that make The Wallawwa such a tranquil and special place to relax before or after your journey.

In the 2½ years we’ve been open we’re delighted to have received so many excellent reviews on Trip Advisor and are proud to be regarded as one of the very best boutique hotels in Sri Lanka. While we try to cater to every guests' needs and tastes, and work extremely hard to ensure friendly and efficient service, it appears we fell short during your stay with us. I'd be interested to hear where you feel we didn't meet your expectations and would be very grateful if you could email me on henry@thewallawwa.com with further details so I can personally look into the feedback you have.

Henry

text:
We stayed at this hotel for two nights when we first arrived in the Country and we did check-in for the last night - but left early.

The building itself is very nice and the rooms are nicely decorated with big bathrooms.  Small items are missing - no hairdryer for the ladies.  

The hotel is very isolated so there is no going anywhere else for a drink or to eat.

The first time we stayed we were charmed and looked after by one of the assistant Managers who used to work for Tea Trails - he appeared to carry the rest of the team.

The rooms are noisy and difficult to get sleep in if the generator is running as it is situated right next to the rooms - this happened on our second night when my husband did not sleep at all.

The food is a problem for vegetarians - there is little choice and despite us asking nicely for them to accommodate us we had great difficulties.  We ate for the first two nights but despite being the only two guests eating on the second night our request for a spicy Sri Lankan curry - hardly a difficult request was not honoured.  Surprisingly we could get a spicier breakfast than we could evening meal.  The breakfasts - we had two - were very good indeed the egg hoppers and fruit were lovely.

Our return visit was a disaster.  The hotel appeared to be virtually full - we gave our dinner order - but the waiter obviously got it wrong - our cashew nuts to nibble with our apperitif arrived with the vegetables for our main meal - which we politely sent back.  Then only one starter arrived - we didn't make a fuss but said there were two - then my husband's main meal arrived at the same time as the second starter - we ate the starter and waited and waited for the second main meal which did not arrive when we asked where it was we were told the waiter didn't speak good english and didn't understand my order so hadn't put one in!  They then took away my husband's now cold meal and came and asked if we wanted dessert!  We pointed out we'd patiently watched the other guests eat - eaten our starters been given our wine and they appeared to have cancelled our main meals without asking us - we asked them if they were cooking them and were told they weren't prepared to discuss that with us we would have to wait and speak to a manager.  We checked out at this stage - our last evening in Sri Lanka ruined - the front of house manager did eventually appear at the same time as our taxi and said he was sorry the waiter didn't speak good english - we said ok - but we spoke to another waiter and all we'd wanted was our food for them to just decide to cancel the order without telling us so we couldn't eat was bad.  The Hotel Manager saw all of this happen and strolled past us with distain and did not attempt to try to help or sort the matter out.

I think the main problem at this hotel is the management - pity it could be nice - but it isn't.

The loungers around the pool are dirty and aren't cleaned and kept nice as in other hotels either.

I would not return or recommend.
title: Poor management means terrible service

text:
Our recent visit to the much-anticipated Cinnamon Life - City of Dreams left us with more questions than answers. With a $1.5 billion price tag attached to the project, we were expecting a top-notch experience. What we got, however, was a mix of dim lighting, smudged plates, and a hospitality team that seemed allergic to genuine warmth.  

Let’s start with parking. Imagine driving in endless spirals inside the building, guided by a small army of staff waving us along. The lighting, triggered by sensors, gave off a vibe more suited to a horror movie than a luxury establishment. A bit of modern traffic management tech wouldn’t hurt, especially given the "dream" budget they’ve been boasting about.  

Next came the restaurant floor. The lift ride up felt more like a trip to a mid-tier office than the entryway to a grand culinary experience. The staff stationed in the corridors stared at us like we’d crash-landed from another planet—awkward, to say the least. Hospitality seemed to have taken the evening off.  

Before dinner, a quick stop at the washroom proved…uninspiring. It had all the charm of a public restroom you’d find in an old building. Definitely not what you’d expect in a place aiming for luxury status.  

We dined at Indiya, a restaurant with a name that promised vibrant flavors. The setting, however, was underwhelming. Overlooking the sea and street, the space felt cramped, with dirty columns, visible litter under the table, and flickering wall lights that seemed to be auditioning for a haunted house.  

The food experience started with plates that came pre-decorated—unfortunately, with smudges and fingerprints. To the waiter’s credit, he promptly apologized and replaced them, explaining that they were cleaned with hot water. Noted. The mutton curry we ordered was tasty but turned cold before we got to the last bites. A warming tray or hot gel plate might’ve saved the day.  

Throughout dinner, the staff maintained a distant politeness that bordered on robotic. They smiled, sure, but with a coldness that felt anything but welcoming. One staff member stood out with a friendly demeanor—perhaps a rare gem in this setting—but the overall vibe was far from the "dream" experience we were sold.  

When we left the restaurant, the lack of hospitality continued. Staff in the corridors and at the entrance seemed preoccupied, hands in pockets, chatting amongst themselves, and ignoring passing guests. Only the reception desk staff managed to crack a smile as we exited.  

The menu options were limited, the pricing ambitious, and the overall experience lackluster. For a place named "City of Dreams," it felt more like a hasty experiment. While the location and investment suggest potential, the execution falls miles short.  

Until some major changes are made, we won’t be returning. For now, the dream feels more like a missed opportunity.
title: Cinnamon Life - City of Dreams: A Reality Check

roomTip: Don’t waste your money on tasteless food in this hotel
text:
Yesterday the 12th of November 2024 my wife and myself visited the Cinnamon Life City of Dreams for lunch with my wife’s sister and mother. We had the lunch buffet at 1 pm in Quizine on the 9th floor. A beautiful restaurant but unfortunately that was as good as it got. The lunch buffet at a cost of 5800Lkr per person plus service charge was absolutely dreadful. The supposedly hot food was cold and I thought it was rather bland in taste. I didn’t have too much as I was saving myself for the spread of Sri Lankan food. I filled my plate with black chicken curry, aubergine, lotus root curry, roasted garlic and rice. I was so looking forward to eating Sri Lankan food in this top rated hotel. I am struggling to find the words to describe how dreadful the food was. To say it was tasteless is an understatement. It was like eating food that had been boiled in water and just coloured with dye. It was stone cold and disgusting, a real let down. I was expecting good food but wow was it disappointing. 
A waiter came and asked us how we were enjoying the food, I asked him have you eaten here and what did he think of the food? He replied “yes I have and it’s not very good”.  For me that was conclusive evidence how awful the food in this place really is. 
With one soft drink each the bill was over 32000Lkr, that’s roughly £80, a complete waste of money. A few days before I had chicken kotthu roti in Galle for £3 and that was amazing. 
Give this place a miss and don’t waste your money, eat in small local restaurants for a fraction of the price.
title: Terrible experience at City of Dreams

text:
Well if you are a person with a disability you can forget accessibility. Tuk tuks are not allowed to take guests to this luxury 5 star entrance (perhaps they lower the tone by allowing local Sri Lankan transport, worried that it might burst the city of dreams...).  You are made to walk the roadway approach uphill to the City of D's... thats if you can walk. If you have a walking impairment. Forget it.

When you eventually get to the only place that serves coffee, the Rs1000 price tag for a latte certainly brings you back to earth with a bump. And remember this I'd the city of dreams, so no such thing as a straight Americano. Turmeric chais, will reduce the inflammation in your body while they inflamed your wallet. Croissants are less than dreamy too.
I came here for the shambles that was #aod's design festival and missed the talk I wanted to see because they changed the time at the last minute and the young lady who was directing me, sent me to the wrong talk anyway. Clearly the City of Dreams is not for people who like their hotel staff awake.

placeInfo/address: 195 Temple Rd, Jaffna 40000 Sri Lanka
text:
Dear Readers,

1. I and my wife stayed at this hotel for two nights (07 to 09 Dec 2024).
 
2. I had booked this hotel through Ms CEYLO TRAVELS,COLOMBO as part of our 14 Nights 15 Days itinerary. "My decision to utilise the services proved to be a big mistake and in fact a disaster."

3. I was apprised by Ceylo Travels that it is a 4-star Heritage property and  it is a pure vegetarian and Alcohol free hotel which was not a big/significant issue in view of my personal habits of drinking and eating.

4. Good Points.
   
   a. The hotel Front Office (FO) is quite positive, responsive and cooperative.
   
   b. The room was quite clean and tidy.
   
   c. The hotel is located only 600 Metres away from the famous Nallur Kandaswamy t. 
   temple, although it did NOT matter that much to us since we had dedicated Cab 
   hired for the entire trip.

   d. The hotel does have a mini swimming pool in front of the FO.

5. Bad Points/Detailed Description.
 
  a. By no standards, this hotel qualifies to be graded as 4-Star or even a proper 3-Star. It is equivalent of a mid segment economy lodge hotel in India.

   b. A similar room with same amenities would cost only Rs 3,000/- to 3,500/- INDIAN 
   Rupees anywhere in India. I state this with full conviction and sense of 
   responsibility.

   c.  The hotel does not have a proper Lobby/seating area  near its Front Office of a 4- 
   Star hotel.

   d.   The photo given in the profile on website is misleading since it is that of a family 
   room of 3 beds located on ground floor. The normal 2 person room allotted to us was 
   on the first floor which was. smaller and it did not have a balcony like the Ground 
   Floor rooms.

  e.  The standard of toiletaries (shampoo ,conditioner and body gel) was poor and 
  substandard.

 6. Food.

 a. The standard of food in terms of variety and quality is VERY POOR and is in fact awful.

 b. One has to choose from a menu with little or NO worthwhile choice. I am attaching the image of the dinner manu for both nights.

c.  The breakfast was served as buffet on both days and the variety and standard is very poor.

d. The basic amenity like FOOD WARMERS for keeping served food WARM was not there. (Photo attached).

7. Feedback Form. The FO produced an Old Visitor Book when I asked for feedback form to render a meaningful feedback which could be utilised by the management for the improvement in future.

8. Summary.

   A. This "so called heritage" hotel is at best  3-star standard and is highly overrated in the reviews. I assume the visitors don't have patience and inclination to write a thorough, realistic and comprehensive review.
   
B.  I would also conclude  that I had made a huge mistake by booking my 14 nights tour to Sri Lanka through Ms CEYLO TRAVELS,COLOMBO. This company is into excessive profiteering and is making a fool of the Foreigner Customers like us after taking 10% advance before reaching Sri Lanka and collecting balance 90% in CASH (USD or INR) immediately on arrival at Colombo.

   C. I would therefore suggest that the Foreigners especially Indians MUST not use the services of this company which is looting its customers in a systematic and organised manner ,knowing fully well that it will be very difficult and highly un-economical for a foreigner to sue them on the Sri Lankan soil.

ANIL KUMAR JOSHI
Indian Citizen
title: 4 Star Jaffna Heritage Hotel: Neither Heritage nor Hotel

text:
We are a family with two kids and we stayed here for two nights, we were booked in by Reddot tours.

The room was fairly neat, there is one man in uniform at the desk who is extremely helpful and courteous. However, the manager is a disaster. 

The room didn't have a tap and there was only a shower. Since washing clothes was difficult the guy at the desk helped us solve that problem. He also had first aid ready when my kids hurt themselves in the pool( which had broken tiles).

The food is pathetic and is overcharged for the quality. The first night we were served a dish that was spoilt. The chef tried to convince me that it was a Srilankan preparation. Having been gastronomic that was an insult. The quantities were very meagre. 

The next day for breakfast we were given puri and an aloo gravy, nothing else. The hot water they served for black coffee had sediments in it. The coffee was instant and lacked flavour too. The manager needs to learn to smile!!
title: Horrible hospitality

placeInfo/address: 195 Temple Rd, Jaffna 40000 Sri Lanka
text:
We arrived after a long hot day travelling.  We were in the annexe and had a less than friendly or efficient welcome. A young lady rushed over from the main building and looked down her nose at us while we completed the registration. No information was given about anything and we weren't given the customary fruit juice as a welcome which we had throughout Sri Lanka, but the room was OK.  Wi-Fi was terrible and only worked in the public rooms. All we wanted was a shower and a meal. My husband tried to have a shower but there was no hot water and the pressure for the cold water was pitiful. There was no phone in the room and only a security guard on duty in the annexe. I went out to the reception area where the security guard dialled the number for the manager. The manager explained that there was no hot water because of a fault in the solar heating and that it would be back on the next afternoon. 
The manager seemed unable to comprehend that not having a hot shower for 24 hours in a country as hot and humid as Sri Lanka is something completely unacceptable for someone from the UK and kept repeating that hot water would be available the next afternoon. I asked for him to find another room in the main building. After 15 mins I phoned him again and he said he was still trying to find a room. This is a small hotel and it shouldn't have been that difficult. It was now 7pm and we were desperate for a shower and dinner so I found another hotel available and we decided to check out. Finally they found us a room but by this time it was too late as we had already decided to move on. 
Customer service at this hotel was diabolical and they really need to get their act together if they want to attract more western visitors.
title: Avoid this hotel

text:

placeInfo/address: 195 Temple Rd, Jaffna 40000 Sri Lanka
roomTip: No light in the lower rooms
text: Unfortunately there isn't so much choice in Sri Lanka in terms of good quality for money hotels and even less so in Jaffna as tourism took a hit during the war and it is just recovering now. I chose Heritage hotel as I thought it would meet some basic standards and more so given that it is marketed as a characteristic luxury hotel. I could forgive the less that clean room, as a resident of Sri Lanka, this is becoming a recurrent theme and the lack of international TV channels ,I know, people don't go on holiday to watch TV, but it would be nice to have the choice, especially as you are paying for amenities that you can't use.  No the nail in this disappointment coffin was the abruptness and utter rudeness of the manager. I was travelling with two girls who were looking for accommodation and wanted to enquire about rooms, rather than being helpful, the manager (nervous about them staying)  was almost shoving them out the door before they could even get their trusty lonely planet out to work out the nearest alternative. Later on the manager was again extremely rude telling me that I had to move out of the reception area as he had a big group of tourists coming and he needed the reception area for them and I couldn't sit there, even though I was a guest at the hotel, he then proceeded to check on us every couple of minutes. To be fair he did try and help briefly but this was completely undermined by his rude attitude and total lack of patience. His whole approach was more that guests should accommodate him, so he could do his job, rather than being a helpful host. Sri Lanka is a beautiful place but it's not easy to get around or work out the best places for food, accommodation etc therefor of course visitors to Sri Lanka might need guidance, not a door in the face and being told where you can and can't sit!!!! As soon as he was rude again to me and my friends I really wanted to leave, I really begrudge paying such a lot of money towards a hotel group that doesn't value its customers.
title: Extremely rude manager!

text:
I was a big fan of the hotel in October 2014.  I still believe its the best in Jaffna for cleanliness.  The staff who speak English are few.  Shanti is the only one that gets anything done. I don't know why people praise the vegetarian food - there are much better restaurants in Jaffna that serve better food.  I don't think canned vegetables is good quality food even if its vegetarian.

Housekeeping cleans irregularly and on Sunday's maybe your room will be cleaned by late afternoon which is unacceptable when working in the room.  Good luck in getting meals at the villa.  I have two unsuccessful attempts for Sunday dinner.  Hopefully some new hotels will open up and give the Heritage Hotel some competition.  I have noted a general decline in six months in clean linens, cockroaches are in the rooms, water problems at the villa and a 3 day internet outage without being informed despite repeated phone calls that it was on at the hotel.
Shanti stands out as excellent staff. The staff at the Villa do not speak any English and if you are guess you can often strangers knock on your door asking for reception.  Stay at the hotel and do not stay at the Vila.   Hotel would be 3 stars and vila one star.

ownerResponse/text:
Dear Harry,

Though it made for trying reading, I thank you for the trouble you’ve taken to write the review you have.   As an owner of Ulpotha, my first reaction upon seeing your name was regret that you did not bring any of your issues to my attention.  I remember meeting you and chatting with you and taking away a most favourable impression.  It’s a shame you gave up on Ulpotha after less that 36 hours of being there (and sorry to hear that you felt you were intruding on us by being in the house, when I can assure that it’s nothing other than a pleasure to share it with our guests).

Secondly, in the context of your comment about Conde Nast, I would like to bring to your attention the most recent Ulpotha press coverage, written for The Huffington Post by a journalist who visited Ulpotha after your stay: http://www.huffingtonpost.com/karin-badt/yoga-retreat-sri-lankan-jungle_b_2400352.html.  I hope this can put to rest the notion that we are ‘resting on [our] yoga mats’ or being complacent and indicate instead that your unfortunate experience appears very much the exception to the rule.  It might also be interesting to know we do not have anyone carrying out PR for Ulpotha - the press coverage we get comes our way simply because people have heard about it and want to write about it.

I am afraid your review is too long and too detailed – and in some places a little too personal – to go into point by point.  However I will deal with what I see as over-arching issues relating to Ulpotha and your experience:  the cost of staying at Ulpotha, the length and timing of your stay and the management and ethos of Ulpotha.

With regards to the costs, I am afraid it is misleading to cite a room rate, as we do not charge such a rate.  Instead we use a per-person per-day rate and this works out to $192.85.  I would like to point out that this includes taxes, all meals, snacks, drinks, two yoga classes a day, a full day excursion per week’s stay, a one hour massage per week’s stay and the use of the sauna, steam bath and hot water bathing area - and of course accommodation.  

It’s worth mentioning, when talking about costs, that the monies paid by visiting guests during the six months Ulpotha is open goes towards running the village and supporting the villagers in and around Ulpotha, including a free Ayurveda clinic, for the entire year (the clinic has treated over 9,000 patients and has had over 30,000 visits).  Ulpotha is not a profit-seeking venture; it is instead an exercise in co-operative, cross-cultural living through sharing of resources.  

There is a good reason why we maintain a minimum stay of one week but recommend two.  Ulpotha is a place that some connect with instantly while others can take longer.  But, by and large, more or less everyone gets it within three days.  Once gotten, the experience is generally a special one.  In your case, it is regrettable that you left as soon as you did, especially in light of the fact you arrived in the middle of the second week of the stay of the majority of the other guests there at the time.  What might have felt at first blush as cliquiness was more to do with the fact that everyone else had come to know each other more than you felt you knew them. As for their conversation, I suppose conversations, however humorous, deep or enchanting they might end up becoming, have to politely start somewhere.  

I was around when I saw you bid farewell to the other guests, who I thought responded to you with an inclusive friendliness (though it didn’t click with me at the time that you were leaving early and disappointed).  I think you’d agree with me that there was a lot of laughter, banter and a general sense of happiness among those guests.  It’s unfortunate that, though you were sharing the same setting, the same care and hospitality, the same accommodation, the same company and the same weather conditions, the results were so different.  

Coming to the weather, what can I say?  I am awfully sorry it was so wet and damp.  In all honesty extended periods of bad weather can play havoc in a place like Ulpotha, designed as it is to be open and one with nature.  Having said that, it is worth pointing out that the rain was exceptional in its persistence - such weather has not been experienced in ages - resulting in a national crisis involving 46 deaths and 300,000 people left homeless (the floods in some areas were worse than the last bad ones in 1957 and the reason why you couldn’t come directly to Ulpotha).  It might be a small consolation and scarcely believable to you, but Ulpotha does happen to be located in Sri Lanka’s Dry Zone.   

You’re right about Ulpotha not being run as a hotel.  It is a naturally beautiful place that is available to be shared with the wonderful people who happen to live there and who effectively are all our hosts.  They are neither ‘staff,’ nor are they ‘practically free’ as you suggest.  Ulpotha is in fact run and managed by a committee of villagers and they strive to do the best they can – and their best is quite exceptional in a unique way.  Their approach is driven by generosity and gracious hospitality.  This is why there is no tipping in Ulpotha.  It would be out of place and its absence is an indication that money is not the focal point here.

As for Suzi, who so kindly helps us out by being the bridge between the villagers and our guests on a day-to-day basis, she is by wide acclaim attentive, caring and gracious to a fault.  Again, as with Ulpotha in general, I am afraid I have to conclude that yours has been a puzzlingly exceptional and unfortunate experience.  

Finally, thank you for the nice things you did have to say – about the food, the scenery, the varied and beautiful fauna and flora and the visiting therapists.  Thank you too for the point about the torches - we had avoided having our own due to the problem of battery disposal.  However, since we can get around this by having wind-up ones, we will have a stock of these handy to lend to those who don’t bring their own as recommended.  

I wish you better luck when you next go on holiday and all the best in 2013,

Viren Perera

placeInfo/name: Ulpotha Yoga Retreat And Ayurveda Resort
text:
What a colossal disappointment.
We'd read the rave reviews about Ulpotha in Condé Nast and various "best yoga retreat" books.
But I'm afraid they must have been written a long time ago.  Perhaps when there was someone competent running the place.

Don't get me wrong: if you were spending $50 per night, Ulpotha would be a lovely, simple, no-frills yoga retreat experience in a charming location.
The trouble is, they charge over $400 per room per night - the sort of rate where you expect, er, a little more.  Especially in Asia where staff are practically free.

We were picked up from Colombo 10 hours later than agreed, because there had been flooding on the roads.  We drove four hours honking our way through slow traffic in a clapped-out minibus, with ants crawling around the floor and a driver who spoke no English.  (The transfer was $120 extra, of course.)

We arrived in the dark, walked down a muddy, rain-sodden path, and were met by S., a rather spaced-out lady who "runs" Ulpotha.  
But no, she doesn't really "run" anything.  She's the sister of one of the owners, and she treats Ulpotha as her private holiday retreat.  The guests are frankly a bit of a nuisance.  She lives in Paris half the year, and Ulpotha the other half.  And Paris seems to have rubbed off on her.  So whenever a guest asks her something, she sighs and shrugs and comes up with a reason why that's not possible.  Then, when pressed, says, "well, I suppose I can see if I can arrange something".  
She took us to our hut.  About a quarter of a mile along dark muddy paths with confusing turns.  No, there's no loo in the hut - you have to find your way back along the dark path about 100 yards, turn left at the bush and right after the tree, and you'll reach a basic loo with only cold water and a piece of pink soap the size of a broad bean.  Or turn left at the tree and round the corner to have a cold shower by a rock.  Just try not to tread on a snake or a bee or a scorpion.  "You did bring torches didn't you?" (don't be silly, at a mere $400 per night, Ulpotha couldn't possibly provide torches...)

S. showed us our room.  Made of mud and thatch, it's open to the elements - charming on a warm day, but less so in driving rain, and with no doors or windows, there's certainly no privacy.
You get a couple of oil lamps that stink of, er, oil. A cupboard, also made of mud - a nest of insects was busy creating a new home in mine... "Be careful", S., says, "the ants might eat your clothes."  Thank you.  There are some cheap incense sticks that smell of Glade, to take away the smell of the oil lamps.  The sounds of the jungle are lovely, but there isn't a view at all - or anywhere to sit and write, for example.  Just two beds and a couple of cushions looking out at a damp bush.  Extra damp because in the middle of the night, there's no way any guests are going to go 200 yards down wet, muddy, dark paths in search of the loo - no, of course we all pee in the nearest tree and hope a snake doesn't take a swipe at our private parts.

Don't get me wrong: I quite enjoy a no-frills holiday.  I worked in the rainforest for months at a time, living in very similar basic conditions.  The difference was, I was paying nothing there.  Ulpotha charge more than the Taj...

I won't bore you with every last detail. 
But to summarise:
The good things:
- The food is vegetarian and local and tasty (though it's basically the same every day: perhaps find a more interesting pudding than a slice of pineapple once in a while?)
- The area is beautiful: a large man-made lake, surrounded by rocky hills, from which, when you climb up them, you can see for miles of untouched landscape.  But sadly none of the huts look at the lake.  (Except one, that you can row out to.  We later learned that it's possible to spend a night there.  Thanks for telling us, S...)
- The butterflies, the birds, the fish, the sunrises.
- The masseurs.  There were two.  They were both exceptional.  You get one free session per week.  

Some less good things:
- The yoga: we were hoping that by flying to Sri Lanka, near the founding home of yoga, there would be a local instructor.  But no, we had a sweet couple from Clapham who did a class a bit more basic than the one at my London gym.
- The Ayurvedic "treatments" - the "doctor" appears to recite exactly the same diagnosis to everyone, after a cursory stroke of their wrist.
- The weather: it rained every day (we were there in December, supposedly dry season)
- The "gardens": the main part of Ulpotha near the swamp is a dark swamp.  Perhaps they're used as paddy fields at other times of year, but when we were there it looked like a chemical waste dump - square pits with muddy water at the bottom; the paths are built on walls of sandy mud around the pits.  They clearly make no effort whatsoever to make it look pretty - perhaps that would upset the natural balance too much.
- The complete lack of information.  S. the manager is so useless and unhelpful that you're expected to divine everything.  They don't even give you a map.
- The laundry: it took forever, and came back dirtier than when we sent it off.  Honestly.
- The cliquiness: because you're thrown together with 20 people (our group were a sweet mix of mostly South Londoners in their 30s and 40s), you spend your entire time answering the same questions - how long you're here, how much yoga do you do back home, how are you finding the food, have you climbed up to the monastery yet, where are you travelling next...)
- The damp.  Everything gets damp.  Damp clothes.  Damp towels.  Damp beds.  damp skin.  Damp squib.
- The party: it's a yoga retreat - sure, the traditional drummers were lovely.  But we really didn't come here to drink beer and Arrack and dance to Britney and M.C. Hammer until 4am.  So we didn't.  But we did have to endure the music pumping all night from our hut (no doors).  And everyone complaining about their hangovers the next day.  yawn.

Actually, the party was the final straw.
We decided to leave.  After three nights.  We couldn't bear to stay another hour in this hell-hole.
Ulpotha make you pay up-front (now I know why), so we ended up spending over $1000 per night for the nights we were there.  Ouch.

But first we needed to find S.  The person "in charge".  No sign of her at 7am yoga.  Or at 9am breakfast.  We wandered through the house (the house is charming, but you always feel like you're intruding on the owners).  Still no sign.  At 10.30 we decided this was getting silly, so we went to her hut.   It just happened to be the loveliest hut of all - with glorious uninterrupted views across paddy fields.  S. was snoring loudly.  We coughed.  We knocked.  In the end we had to yell.  "Sorry to wake you, but we'd like to leave today - is there someone else on duty we should be asking for help?" - "Sorry, it is me who's on duty. But I was up till 4am."

Really, but have you ever heard of a place that charges $400 per room per night, where the manager says "sod the guests, I'm hungover, I think I'll sleep a bit longer"?  
And that pretty much sums up Ulpotha.  You fit into our routine - this is how we do things here - you were dumb enough to give us your money in advance, now you'd better grin and bear it... Breathe... If you're not enjoying it it's not our fault.

There's no concept of service here.  No "what could we do to make your stay more enjoyable?"  Let's think: if I were running a $400/night establishment, I might say "it's raining: let's send umbrellas round to people's huts so they don't get wet?" - naah, at Ulpotha you just get wet.  Or I might ask "Would you like a wake up call before morning yoga?".  Naah, at Ulpotha you have to use your traditional iPhone (even though there's nowhere to plug it in).  Or I might think - "after their 4 hour much-delayed hellish journey, let's get them a hot towel and a refreshing juice to make them feel welcome".  Naah, at Ulpotha you can make yourself a cup of tea from the pot, mind your head, and if you wait until supper in 2 hours' time you can help yourself to  juice then.  What do you think we are, a hotel?!

Ulpotha could be utopia if they made a little effort.  But they're resting on their yoga mats.  The place reeks of smugness, disdain and terminal decay.  
Don't waste your money.
title: Please don't waste your money

Okay, so I'm an American and I'm spoiled.  
Not many Americans go to Ulpotha--or Sri Lanka, for that matter...I was the only one during my week--and the only complainer.
Let me start:  no hot water, no electricity, bathroom in a separate (pitch dark) hut at a distance in the jungle, "hut" with a pitch dark cove for clothing--making it impossible to find anything.
Food abundant but monotonous in the extreme--all vegan and all served at a tepid temperature--no alcohol.
Good yoga and interesting people (mostly female) who seemed to feel they were in Paradise.  My paradise has hot water and light.
title: Great yoga--lousy accomodations

placeInfo/address: 395 Bambarakelle Road, Nuwara Eliya 22200 Sri Lanka
text:
We chose this hotel for our honeymoon, expecting a peaceful and enjoyable getaway. Unfortunately, our experience was anything but that.
Right from the start, there were multiple service issues. On more than one occasion, the buggy service was unreliable at times it didn’t arrive at all, and we were left walking in the freezing cold at night just to reach the restaurant (mind you this is the best suit that is available in the hotel). On another morning, we requested a buggy around 6:30am to leave for Horton Plains, but were told that buggies weren’t available until 7am. That was fine we understood that could be a policy but what followed was deeply unsettling.
That morning, since we had no mobile signal during the hike, we were completely unaware that our families had been frantically trying to reach us. It turns out the hotel had contacted them, informing them that we hadn’t had dinner or breakfast (which was incorrect, we had ordered room service and skipped breakfast by choice). They further assumed that we hadn’t returned to the hotel at all the previous night. What shocked us was that no one had even checked to see if our car was in the car park before making such a serious assumption (we were out of the hotel only for 6 hours). We strongly felt they assumed we had left without settling our bill. This premature conclusion caused unnecessary panic for our loved ones and completely ruined the mood of our trip.
What’s worse is how the staff responded when we returned. Instead of a simple apology or acknowledgement, we were met with stares and uncomfortable looks from the team. The General Manager, Mr. Pushpitha Udawatta, attempted to justify what had happened rather than accept responsibility, which we found unprofessional and dismissive. If you read through other one-star reviews, you’ll notice this seems to be a pattern. It’s extremely disappointing to see that this kind of behavior seems to be tolerated or ignored by upper management above him. 
There were smaller but still unpleasant moments throughout for example, when we asked to be seated away from the sun at breakfast, a waiter gave us a look and refused our request quite rudely. These interactions, while minor on their own, added up and reflected a lack of hospitality and warmth that any guest, especially honeymooners should expect.
When we expressed our disappointment and told them we would be leaving a review, they offered to reduce our remaining balance by 50%. While we initially insisted on paying the full amount, we eventually ended up paying the discounted total, not because the experience deserved it, but simply because we were drained and wanted to leave without further conflict.
We had another night booked but chose to check out early. We truly hope that someone in the hotel’s upper management (above Pushpitha) or ownership takes a serious look at how these situations are handled. Until then, we would not recommend this property to anyone especially not for a special occasion like a honeymoon.
title: A Disappointing and Stressful Honeymoon Experience

text:
I booked The Golden Ridge Hotel in Nuwara Eliya expecting a peaceful and premium experience. What I got instead was one of the most uncomfortable, misleading, and intimidating stays I’ve ever had.

The hotel looks decent from the outside, but that’s where the illusion ends. The rooms are tiny, and the so-called balcony is barely a ledge — nothing like what’s shown in the pictures. It’s clear this property has invested in clever photography and false advertising to attract bookings.

When I politely mentioned my dissatisfaction, I was approached by a man who seemed unofficial, aggressive, and completely unprofessional. He told me directly,

“You either stay here or pay USD 150 to upgrade.”
The way it was said felt threatening and completely unacceptable — not the kind of tone any guest, especially an international traveler, should face at a hotel claiming to be “5-star.”

He even claimed “no hotels here have balconies,” which is simply not true. It felt like a rehearsed excuse to trap guests into upgrades. Based on my experience, it seems like the hotel may be collaborating with local tour agents to deliberately mislead tourists and then push them for more money on arrival.

The overall hospitality was poor, the experience felt dishonest and unsafe, and I would strongly caution any foreign traveler from booking here.

There are far better places in Nuwara Eliya that respect guests and actually deliver what they promise. Golden Ridge is not one of them. Avoid.
title: Scam Alert

text:
We stayed for two nights at the Golden Ridge Hotel in February. We had high expectations as it is a five star hotel. We were looking forward to our stay. We were touring Sri Lanka and this was the first hotel that really did not meet our expectations. The hotel is not of five star quality. Our room was very old and the furniture all chipped. There were holes in the walls next to the curtains. The bathroom was worn out, with chipped tiles and yellow grouting in the shower cabin. The sink was chipped. Nothing in our room was of five star quality. It was not even 4 star standards. We were met with hostility by the reception and the management when we raised our concerns. In general, cleaners, porters and cooks provide excellent service, while managers are mostly talking to each other at the reception and not particularly interested in the customers needs. 
The person in charge of the pool Akita was extremely lovely and very helpful. He knows how to talk to customers and provided some helpful information about the area. The gardens are very well maintained and pretty. The restaurants provides beautiful choices of cuisine including very fresh produce. The chefs and staff at restaurant are very lovely and courteous.
title: Disappointing room not of five star quality
